newsitem.title: GERMANY: German FDP rules out tax hikes to plug budget gaps.
newsitem.headline: German FDP rules out tax hikes to plug budget gaps.

text.p: Germany's Free Democrats (FDP), junior partners in Chancellor Helmut Kohl's coalition government, adopted a resolution on Sunday against tax hikes to plug shortfalls in the state budget.

Delegates at a party congress backed a leadership motion which also said the FDP would not give up on a coalition deal to cut a tax raised to pay for German unification by two percentage points next year.

Christian Democrats in Kohl's ruling alliance have floated the idea of an increase in petrol tax this year to cover a big shortfall in state revenues and enable Germany to qualify for European monetary union (EMU).
FDP parliamentary leader Hermann Otto Solms told around 660 delegates earlier that he expected his coalition partners to stand by the agreement to cut the solidarity tax.
"Anything else would undermine the foundations of this coalition," Solms said.
The FDP, which provides the Kohl government with its 12-seat majority, is hoping to survive as a parliamentary party at next year's general election by campaigning for tax cuts.

But most Germans are sceptical that the party will hold to its line. A survey on Saturday by the Forsa polling group for RTL television found that 68 percent of Germans expected the FDP to give up its "no" to tax increases under pressure from their bigger coalition partners.
